text.p: Shares in British drug software and contract research group Oxford Molecular Group Plc fell sharply on Monday, although the price drop left analysts and traders scratching their heads for a specific reason.
Shares in Oxford Molecular slid 44 pence, or 15.7 percent, to 236.5 pence in thin volume, to trade at the lowest levels for 18 months.

One market maker in the stock said it had been subjected to "patchy selling". He said the share, which is often lumped together with biotech stocks, was taking a beating in line with that sector in recent months.
"I think it has been overdone and could turn tomorrow," he said.
Oxford Molecular started the year at 349 pence per share and is currently trading 50 percent below its February peak of 469 pence.
Marker rumours laid some of the blame for the price fall at the door of Merrill Lynch, although analysts there said they did not cover the stock.

Other analysts said there had been disappointment earlier this year when Anglo-Dutch publishers Reed Elsevier Plc acquired U.S. software group MDL Information Systems Inc, which Oxford had been strongly tipped to buy.
